title: Hot Dog Sales: Stemplots and Outliers
question_text:
For the past $24$ days, Oscar has been keeping track of the number of hot dogs sold daily at his hot dog cart. His data is displayed in the stemplot below.

Which of the following statements accurately describes the outliers in this distribution?

choices.text:
There is only one outlier and it occurs at 12
hot dogs.

There is only one outlier and it occurs at
62
hot dogs.

There are two outliers. One outlier is at
12
hot dogs and the other outlier is at
62
hot dogs.

There are three outliers. One outlier is at
12
hot dogs, another is at
57
hot dogs, and another is at
62
hot dogs.

solution:
To determine whether there are any outliers, we first need to find the values associated with
Q
1
and
Q
3
.

The median is the middle value (or average of the two middle values) when the observations are arranged in order. With
24
observations, we are looking for the average of the
12
th
and
13
th
highest values.

To find these values, start from the bottom of the stemplot and work your way upward. Remember to always start from the left value in a row since the values are arranged in rows from lowest value to highest value.

Created for Albert.io. Copyright 2016. All rights reserved.



The
12
th
and
13
th
highest values are boxed in blue in the graph above. The corresponding values are
37
and
38
hot dogs. The average of these two numbers is
37.5
which represents the median of the distribution.

More importantly, in this case,
37.5
is the value which divides the distribution into a top half of numbers and a bottom half of numbers. The red mark above shows where the dividing line is.

To find the
Q
1
value, we need to find the middle of the lower
12
values. This would be the average of the
6
th
and
7
th
values when the observations are arranged from smallest to largest. These values are circled in black above and correspond with
29
and
30
hot dogs. The average of
29
and
30
is
29.5
so the
Q
1
value is
29.5
.

To find
Q
3
, we need to find the middle of the
12
values that fall above the median. This would be the average of the
18
th
and
19
th
values when the observations are arranged from smallest to largest. These values are also circled in black in the graph shown above. Since both the
18
th
and
19
th
values are at
42
, the
Q
3
value is
42
.

A low outlier is an observation that falls below
Q
1
−
1.5
I
Q
R
. Therefore, a low outlier would be a value that is less than
29.5
−
1.5
(
12.5
)
or a value less than
10.75
. No such values exist, so there are no low outliers.

Since we know that
12
is not an outlier, at this point, we can eliminate Choices 'B', 'D', and 'E'.

A high outlier is an observation that falls above
Q
3
+
1.5
I
Q
R
. Therefore, a high outlier would be a value that is greater than
42
+
1.5
(
12.5
)
or a value greater than
60.75
. The only value displayed in the stemplot which is greater than
60.75
is
62
which makes
62
the one and only outlier in this distribution.

Note: You could also determine whether or not there are outliers by entering all
24
values into your
T
I
83
/
84
calculator and having the calculator produce a modified boxplot. Instructions are:

Press STAT
While EDIT is highlighted, press Enter
In L1 enter all
24
observations. Be careful to enter the number of hot dogs sold with the correct frequencies.
Press 2nd
Press Y=
While Plot1 is highlighted, press Enter
Highlight On
Choose the modified boxplot (showing outliers) as the Type of graph
Ensure that L1 is identified as the Xlist
Press ZOOM
Press 9

Your calculator will show you the corresponding boxplot, and you will be able to see that there is only one high outlier.

Choice 'C' is the correct answer.
